questions.text: While examining mRNA samples from both healthy and affected tissues, a scientist identified an mRNA unique to the diseased tissue. The sequence found in this specific mRNA is AGUCUCA. What would be the sequence of the DNA strand that served as the template during transcription of this mRNA?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) TGAGACT

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • To determine the template DNA strand sequence from the given mRNA sequence , we follow these steps:
  • • template DNA strand
  • • mRNA sequence
  • • mRNA Sequence : The given sequence is AGUCUCA . mRNA is complementary to the DNA template strand and replaces thymine (T) with uracil (U). The direction of mRNA is 5’ → 3’ , unless otherwise stated. Step 1: Create the Non-Template (Coding) DNA Strand : The coding DNA strand (non-template strand) has the same sequence as the mRNA but U is replaced with T . mRNA: 5’-AGUCUCA-3’ Coding DNA strand: 5’-AGTCTCA-3’ Step 2: Determine the Template DNA Strand : The template DNA strand is complementary to the coding strand, and it is read in the 3’ → 5’ direction . Coding strand: 5’-AGTCTCA-3’ Template strand (complementary): 3’-TCAGAGT-5’ Step 3: Adjust for Directionality : When writing the template strand in the standard 5’ → 3’ direction , we reverse it: Template strand: 5’-TGAGACT-3’
  • • mRNA Sequence : The given sequence is AGUCUCA . mRNA is complementary to the DNA template strand and replaces thymine (T) with uracil (U). The direction of mRNA is 5’ → 3’ , unless otherwise stated.

  • • DNA template strand
  • • The direction of mRNA is 5’ → 3’ , unless otherwise stated.

  • • Step 1: Create the Non-Template (Coding) DNA Strand : The coding DNA strand (non-template strand) has the same sequence as the mRNA but U is replaced with T . mRNA: 5’-AGUCUCA-3’ Coding DNA strand: 5’-AGTCTCA-3’
  • • Step 1: Create the Non-Template (Coding) DNA Strand
  • • coding DNA strand
  • • U is replaced with T
  • • mRNA: 5’-AGUCUCA-3’ Coding DNA strand: 5’-AGTCTCA-3’
  • • mRNA: 5’-AGUCUCA-3’
  • • 5’-AGUCUCA-3’
  • • Coding DNA strand: 5’-AGTCTCA-3’
  • • 5’-AGTCTCA-3’
  • • Step 2: Determine the Template DNA Strand : The template DNA strand is complementary to the coding strand, and it is read in the 3’ → 5’ direction . Coding strand: 5’-AGTCTCA-3’ Template strand (complementary): 3’-TCAGAGT-5’
  • • Step 2: Determine the Template DNA Strand
  • • template DNA strand
  • • complementary
  • • 3’ → 5’ direction
  • • Coding strand: 5’-AGTCTCA-3’ Template strand (complementary): 3’-TCAGAGT-5’
  • • Coding strand: 5’-AGTCTCA-3’
  • • 5’-AGTCTCA-3’
  • • Template strand (complementary): 3’-TCAGAGT-5’
  • • 3’-TCAGAGT-5’
  • • Step 3: Adjust for Directionality : When writing the template strand in the standard 5’ → 3’ direction , we reverse it: Template strand: 5’-TGAGACT-3’
  • • Step 3: Adjust for Directionality
  • • 5’ → 3’ direction
  • • Template strand: 5’-TGAGACT-3’
  • • Template strand: 5’-TGAGACT-3’
  • • 5’-TGAGACT-3’
  • • Thus, the correct answer is D. TGAGACT .
  • • D. TGAGACT
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. TCAGAGT: This sequence is complementary to the mRNA but written in the 3’ → 5’ direction . It must be reversed to match the 5’ → 3’ standard.
  • • Option A. TCAGAGT:
  • • 3’ → 5’ direction
  • • Option B. AGUCTGA: This contains a U , which is found in RNA, not DNA.
  • • Option B. AGUCTGA:
  • • U
  • • Option C. ATCGATC: This sequence does not align with the mRNA or its complementary template strand.
  • • Option C. ATCGATC:

  • ➤ template DNA strand

  • ➤ TGAGACT

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with hepatosplenomegaly, bone pain, and pancytopenia. On histological examination of the bone marrow, characteristic wrinkled tissue paper appearance is noted and shown. This inherited disorder will cause accumulation of which of following lipids in this child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Glucocerebrosides

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The child’s presentation, combined with the "wrinkled tissue paper appearance" of cells on histology, is highly suggestive of Gaucher's disease . Gaucher's disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme β-glucocerebrosidase (β-glucosylceramidase) . This enzyme defect leads to the accumulation of glucocerebrosides in macrophages, forming Gaucher cells with the characteristic wrinkled appearance.
  • • "wrinkled tissue paper appearance"
  • • Gaucher's disease
  • • β-glucocerebrosidase (β-glucosylceramidase)
  • • glucocerebrosides
  • • Gaucher cells
  • • Key features of Gaucher's disease:
  • • Hepatosplenomegaly – Due to accumulation of glucocerebrosides in liver and spleen. Bone pain and skeletal abnormalities – Caused by infiltration of bone marrow. Pancytopenia – Due to replacement of bone marrow by Gaucher cells, leading to anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia. No cherry-red spots or neurodegeneration in non-neuronopathic forms.
  • • Hepatosplenomegaly – Due to accumulation of glucocerebrosides in liver and spleen.
  • • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • • Bone pain and skeletal abnormalities – Caused by infiltration of bone marrow.
  • • Bone pain and skeletal abnormalities
  • • Pancytopenia – Due to replacement of bone marrow by Gaucher cells, leading to anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia.
  • • Pancytopenia
  • • No cherry-red spots or neurodegeneration in non-neuronopathic forms.
  • • No cherry-red spots or neurodegeneration
  • • Histology of bone marrow reveals Gaucher cells – enlarged macrophages with a wrinkled tissue paper appearance , as seen in the provided image.
  • • Gaucher cells
  • • wrinkled tissue paper appearance
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Ceramides: Ceramides are precursors for sphingolipids and are not the primary substrate accumulating in Gaucher's disease.
  • • Option A. Ceramides:
  • • Option B. Sphingomyelins: Accumulation of sphingomyelin occurs in Niemann-Pick disease due to sphingomyelinase deficiency, which presents with hepatosplenomegaly, cherry-red spots, and neurodegeneration.
  • • Option B. Sphingomyelins:
  • • Niemann-Pick disease
  • • Option D. Galactocerebrosides: Galactocerebrosides accumulate in Krabbe disease , a lysosomal storage disorder characterized by neurodegeneration but without hepatosplenomegaly.
  • • Option D. Galactocerebrosides:
  • • Krabbe disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gaucher's disease is caused by a deficiency of β-glucocerebrosidase , leading to accumulation of glucocerebrosides in macrophages. The presence of hepatosplenomegaly, bone pain, pancytopenia, and "wrinkled tissue paper appearance" on histology confirms the diagnosis.
  • ➤ Gaucher's disease
  • ➤ β-glucocerebrosidase
  • ➤ glucocerebrosides
  • ➤ "wrinkled tissue paper appearance"

questions.text: Best method to detect the given structure of protein is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) X-ray crystallography

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image provided depicts an alpha-helix , which is a secondary structure of a protein. To determine the structure of proteins at the atomic level, X-ray Crystallography used:
  • • alpha-helix
  • • secondary structure
  • • X-ray Crystallography used:
  • • It is the gold standard for determining secondary, tertiary, and quaternary structures of proteins. X-ray crystallography works by analyzing the diffraction pattern of X-rays when they pass through a crystallized protein. This method provides high-resolution 3D structures of proteins, making it the best choice for identifying structures like the alpha-helix shown in the diagram.
  • • It is the gold standard for determining secondary, tertiary, and quaternary structures of proteins. X-ray crystallography works by analyzing the diffraction pattern of X-rays when they pass through a crystallized protein. This method provides high-resolution 3D structures of proteins, making it the best choice for identifying structures like the alpha-helix shown in the diagram.
  • • secondary, tertiary, and quaternary structures
  • • X-ray crystallography works by analyzing the diffraction pattern of X-rays when they pass through a crystallized protein. This method provides high-resolution 3D structures of proteins, making it the best choice for identifying structures like the alpha-helix shown in the diagram.
  • • X-ray crystallography works by analyzing the diffraction pattern of X-rays when they pass through a crystallized protein.
  • • This method provides high-resolution 3D structures of proteins, making it the best choice for identifying structures like the alpha-helix shown in the diagram.
  • • alpha-helix
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Mass spectrometry: Useful for analyzing the primary structure of a protein, but it cannot detect secondary or higher-order structures like the alpha-helix.
  • • Option A. Mass spectrometry:
  • • primary structure
  • • Option B. Edman’s technique: This method determines the amino acid sequence (primary structure) of proteins but does not reveal secondary or tertiary structures.
  • • Option B. Edman’s technique:
  • • amino acid sequence
  • • Option D. NMR spectrometry: NMR is used to study proteins in solution, especially non-crystallizable proteins, and can analyze secondary, tertiary, and quaternary structures . However, for crystallizable proteins like this one, X-ray crystallography is preferred due to its higher resolution.
  • • Option D. NMR spectrometry:
  • • secondary, tertiary, and quaternary structures
  • • X-ray crystallography

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The best method to detect the secondary structure of proteins, such as the alpha-helix , is X-ray crystallography .
  • ➤ best method to detect the secondary structure of proteins, such as the alpha-helix
  • ➤ X-ray crystallography

questions.text: A young man goes to a clinic and tells the doctor that he feels unwell after eating dairy products, leading to gas, bloating, and diarrhea. When he stops eating dairy, these problems go away. To manage his symptoms, he could benefit from a supplement containing which of the following enzyme?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) β – Galactosidase

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The symptoms described in the question (gas, bloating, and diarrhea after eating dairy products) are classic signs of lactose intolerance . In lactose intolerance:
  • • lactose intolerance
  • • Lactose , a disaccharide present in dairy products, cannot be digested properly due to a deficiency of the enzyme lactase . Lactase is an enzyme that breaks down lactose into its two monosaccharide components: glucose and galactose . Lactase is also called β-galactosidase because it breaks the beta-glycosidic bond between glucose and galactose in lactose.
  • • Lactose , a disaccharide present in dairy products, cannot be digested properly due to a deficiency of the enzyme lactase .
  • • Lactose
  • • lactase
  • • Lactase is an enzyme that breaks down lactose into its two monosaccharide components: glucose and galactose .
  • • glucose
  • • galactose
  • • Lactase is also called β-galactosidase because it breaks the beta-glycosidic bond between glucose and galactose in lactose.
  • • β-galactosidase
  • • beta-glycosidic bond
  • • When lactose remains undigested in the intestines, it undergoes fermentation by gut bacteria, producing gas (hydrogen and methane), leading to bloating and diarrhea .
  • • gas
  • • bloating
  • • diarrhea
  • • Treatment:
  • • Treatment:
  • • To manage symptoms, lactase (β-galactosidase) supplements can be given to aid the digestion of lactose.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. α - amylase: α-amylase is an enzyme that breaks down starch (polysaccharides) into maltose and glucose. It does not act on lactose, so it is not useful for lactose intolerance.
  • • Option A. α - amylase:
  • • Option B. α - Galactosidase: α-galactosidase breaks down complex sugars found in certain vegetables and legumes (like raffinose and stachyose), but it does not act on lactose.
  • • Option B. α - Galactosidase:
  • • Option D. β - Galactocerebrosidase: This enzyme is involved in the breakdown of galactocerebrosides , which are components of myelin. A deficiency of this enzyme leads to Krabbe disease , a lysosomal storage disorder. It has no role in lactose digestion.
  • • Option D. β - Galactocerebrosidase:
  • • galactocerebrosides
  • • Krabbe disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lactose intolerance occurs due to lactase deficiency. The enzyme β-galactosidase (lactase) breaks down lactose into glucose and galactose and can be given as a supplement to manage symptoms.
  • ➤ Lactose intolerance
  • ➤ β-galactosidase (lactase)

questions.text: A section of intestinal brush border membrane is shown in picture. Identify the glucose transporters present at marked points X and Y:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) X-SGLT-1, Y-GLUT-2

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In the intestinal brush border membrane, glucose absorption occurs through a coordinated action of transporters located at specific sites:
  • • glucose absorption
  • • X (Apical membrane): SGLT-1
  • • X (Apical membrane): SGLT-1
  • • The Sodium-Glucose Linked Transporter 1 (SGLT-1) is located on the apical membrane (facing the intestinal lumen). SGLT-1 facilitates the secondary active transport of glucose and galactose into the epithelial cells. It utilizes the sodium gradient created by the Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase pump.
  • • The Sodium-Glucose Linked Transporter 1 (SGLT-1) is located on the apical membrane (facing the intestinal lumen).
  • • Sodium-Glucose Linked Transporter 1 (SGLT-1)
  • • apical membrane
  • • SGLT-1 facilitates the secondary active transport of glucose and galactose into the epithelial cells. It utilizes the sodium gradient created by the Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase pump.
  • • secondary active transport
  • • sodium gradient
  • • Y (Basolateral membrane): GLUT-2
  • • Y (Basolateral membrane): GLUT-2
  • • The GLUT-2 transporter is located on the basolateral membrane (facing the interstitial fluid and blood). GLUT-2 mediates the facilitated diffusion of glucose and galactose from the epithelial cells into the bloodstream.
  • • The GLUT-2 transporter is located on the basolateral membrane (facing the interstitial fluid and blood).
  • • GLUT-2
  • • basolateral membrane
  • • GLUT-2 mediates the facilitated diffusion of glucose and galactose from the epithelial cells into the bloodstream.
  • • facilitated diffusion
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. X-SGLT-2, Y-GLUT-2: SGLT-2 is found in the kidney proximal tubules , not in the intestines.
  • • Option A. X-SGLT-2, Y-GLUT-2:
  • • kidney proximal tubules
  • • Option B. X-GLUT-3, Y-SGLT-1: GLUT-3 is primarily involved in glucose transport in the brain and neurons , not in the intestines.
  • • Option B. X-GLUT-3, Y-SGLT-1:
  • • brain and neurons
  • • Option D. X-GLUT-2, Y-SGLT-2: GLUT-2 is present on the basolateral side , but SGLT-2 is kidney-specific and not found in the intestinal brush border.
  • • Option D. X-GLUT-2, Y-SGLT-2:
  • • basolateral side

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the intestinal brush border:
  • ➤ SGLT-1 on the apical membrane absorbs glucose and galactose via sodium-dependent active transport. GLUT-2 on the basolateral membrane facilitates glucose diffusion into the blood.
  • ➤ SGLT-1 on the apical membrane absorbs glucose and galactose via sodium-dependent active transport.
  • ➤ SGLT-1
  • ➤ apical membrane
  • ➤ GLUT-2 on the basolateral membrane facilitates glucose diffusion into the blood.
  • ➤ GLUT-2
  • ➤ basolateral membrane

questions.text: A newborn girl, full-term at birth, was taken to a pediatrician due to her inability to grow and gain weight. After checking her six-month history, it was noted that she had ongoing acidosis, which wasn't fixed by thiamine. Upon physical inspection, she had a small head, weak muscle tone, and low muscle bulk. Her blood test showed high levels of pyruvate. Which of the following statements about her condition is not true?

options.label: C
options.text: Lactate levels increase in the blood.

options.label: D
options.text: Giving Vitamin B6 will help in her treatment.

questions.correct_answer: D. Giving Vitamin B6 will help in her treatment.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Giving Vitamin B6 will help in her treatment.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Vitamin B6 is not involved in the PDH complex. It is primarily required for transamination reactions (like pyruvate to alanine), but it does not correct the underlying PDH deficiency.
  • • Vitamin B6
  • • The clinical presentation of this newborn strongly suggests a deficiency in the Pyruvate Dehydrogenase (PDH) complex , a condition that results in impaired conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA. This causes pyruvate accumulation, leading to increased levels of lactate and alanine .
  • • Pyruvate Dehydrogenase (PDH) complex
  • • lactate
  • • alanine
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Acetyl CoA levels decrease: True. The PDH complex catalyzes the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA in the link reaction. In PDH deficiency, this conversion is impaired, leading to decreased acetyl-CoA levels.
  • • Option A. Acetyl CoA levels decrease:
  • • pyruvate to acetyl-CoA
  • • Option B. Pyruvate and Alanine levels increase: True. Pyruvate accumulates because it cannot enter the PDH pathway. Pyruvate is then diverted to form alanine via transamination (catalyzed by alanine transaminase). This results in increased blood levels of both pyruvate and alanine.
  • • Option B. Pyruvate and Alanine levels increase:
  • • Pyruvate accumulates
  • • alanine
  • • Option C. Lactate levels increase in the blood: True. When pyruvate cannot enter the PDH complex, it is instead converted to lactate via lactate dehydrogenase. This leads to lactic acidosis , which explains the ongoing acidosis in the patient.
  • • Option C. Lactate levels increase in the blood:
  • • lactate
  • • lactic acidosis
  • • The Pyruvate Dehydrogenase Complex requires the following cofactors:
  • • The Pyruvate Dehydrogenase Complex requires the following cofactors:
  • • Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) Vitamin B2 (FAD) Vitamin B3 (NAD⁺) Vitamin B5 (Coenzyme A) Lipoic acid
  • • Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) Vitamin B2 (FAD) Vitamin B3 (NAD⁺) Vitamin B5 (Coenzyme A) Lipoic acid
  • • Vitamin B2 (FAD) Vitamin B3 (NAD⁺) Vitamin B5 (Coenzyme A) Lipoic acid
  • • Vitamin B2 (FAD) Vitamin B3 (NAD⁺) Vitamin B5 (Coenzyme A) Lipoic acid
  • • Vitamin B3 (NAD⁺) Vitamin B5 (Coenzyme A) Lipoic acid
  • • Vitamin B3 (NAD⁺)
  • • Vitamin B5 (Coenzyme A)
  • • Lipoic acid
  • • Additional Notes:
  • • Additional Notes:
  • • PDH deficiency is an X-linked disorder and is one of the causes of congenital lactic acidosis . Symptoms include poor growth, developmental delay, weak muscle tone, and lactic acidosis. Thiamine (Vitamin B1) supplementation may help in some cases, but it was already noted to have failed in this patient.
  • • PDH deficiency is an X-linked disorder and is one of the causes of congenital lactic acidosis .
  • • X-linked disorder
  • • congenital lactic acidosis
  • • Symptoms include poor growth, developmental delay, weak muscle tone, and lactic acidosis.
  • • Thiamine (Vitamin B1) supplementation may help in some cases, but it was already noted to have failed in this patient.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Pyruvate Dehydrogenase Complex deficiency , acetyl-CoA decreases, while pyruvate, lactate, and alanine levels increase. Vitamin B6 is not part of the PDH complex, so it does not help in treatment.
  • ➤ Pyruvate Dehydrogenase Complex deficiency
  • ➤ Vitamin B6

questions.text: The molecule marked by blue question mark can be all the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Glycerol

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The image represents the metabolic exchanges between the liver and muscle during processes like gluconeogenesis and glycolysis.
  • • liver
  • • muscle
  • • Pyruvate , Lactate , and Alanine are intermediates that participate in metabolic cycles like: Cori Cycle : Lactate produced in the muscles from anaerobic glycolysis is transported to the liver, where it is converted back to glucose. Cahill Cycle : Alanine is produced in the muscles from the transamination of pyruvate. It travels to the liver, where it is converted back into glucose. Pyruvate : Directly involved as an intermediate in glycolysis and gluconeogenesis. Glycerol , however, is different: Glycerol comes from the breakdown of triglycerides (lipolysis) in adipose tissue. It enters the liver for gluconeogenesis but is not produced by muscle cells as part of glucose metabolism.
  • • Pyruvate , Lactate , and Alanine are intermediates that participate in metabolic cycles like: Cori Cycle : Lactate produced in the muscles from anaerobic glycolysis is transported to the liver, where it is converted back to glucose. Cahill Cycle : Alanine is produced in the muscles from the transamination of pyruvate. It travels to the liver, where it is converted back into glucose. Pyruvate : Directly involved as an intermediate in glycolysis and gluconeogenesis.
  • • Pyruvate
  • • Lactate
  • • Alanine
  • • Cori Cycle : Lactate produced in the muscles from anaerobic glycolysis is transported to the liver, where it is converted back to glucose. Cahill Cycle : Alanine is produced in the muscles from the transamination of pyruvate. It travels to the liver, where it is converted back into glucose. Pyruvate : Directly involved as an intermediate in glycolysis and gluconeogenesis.
  • • Cori Cycle : Lactate produced in the muscles from anaerobic glycolysis is transported to the liver, where it is converted back to glucose.
  • • Cori Cycle
  • • Cahill Cycle : Alanine is produced in the muscles from the transamination of pyruvate. It travels to the liver, where it is converted back into glucose.
  • • Cahill Cycle
  • • Pyruvate : Directly involved as an intermediate in glycolysis and gluconeogenesis.
  • • Pyruvate
  • • Glycerol , however, is different: Glycerol comes from the breakdown of triglycerides (lipolysis) in adipose tissue. It enters the liver for gluconeogenesis but is not produced by muscle cells as part of glucose metabolism.
  • • Glycerol
  • • Glycerol comes from the breakdown of triglycerides (lipolysis) in adipose tissue. It enters the liver for gluconeogenesis but is not produced by muscle cells as part of glucose metabolism.
  • • Glycerol comes from the breakdown of triglycerides (lipolysis) in adipose tissue.
  • • breakdown of triglycerides
  • • It enters the liver for gluconeogenesis but is not produced by muscle cells as part of glucose metabolism.
  • • is not produced by muscle cells
  • • Since glycerol does not originate from muscle metabolism, it cannot be the molecule marked by the blue question mark in the diagram.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Pyruvate: Pyruvate is formed in muscle cells during glycolysis and can enter gluconeogenesis in the liver.
  • • Option A. Pyruvate:
  • • Option B. Lactate: Lactate is a product of anaerobic glycolysis in muscles. It travels to the liver via the Cori Cycle to be converted back to glucose.
  • • Option B. Lactate:
  • • Cori Cycle
  • • Option C. Alanine: Alanine is derived from pyruvate through transamination in the muscle and participates in the Cahill Cycle , contributing to gluconeogenesis in the liver.
  • • Option C. Alanine:
  • • Cahill Cycle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glycerol cannot be produced by muscles as part of glucose metabolism. It originates from the breakdown of triglycerides in adipose tissue, not from glucose-related cycles like the Cori or Cahill cycles.

  • ➤ breakdown of triglycerides

questions.text: A 2-week-old infant is brought to the pediatric clinic with jaundice, poor feeding, and failure to gain weight. The parents report that they have been feeding the baby with regular cow's milk formula since birth. Lab investigations of urine showed positive test for reducing substances but negative for glucose. A diagnosis of an inherited metabolic disorder is suspected. Which enzyme deficiency is most consistent with this infant's presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The presentation of jaundice, poor feeding, failure to gain weight , and the positive test for reducing substances but negative for glucose indicates classical galactosemia . This condition is caused by a deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT) .
  • • jaundice, poor feeding, failure to gain weight
  • • positive test for reducing substances but negative for glucose
  • • classical galactosemia
  • • galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT)
  • • Mechanism of Disease :
  • • Mechanism of Disease
  • • In classical galactosemia, the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase is deficient. This enzyme normally converts galactose-1-phosphate (derived from lactose in milk) into glucose-1-phosphate. The deficiency leads to accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate and its metabolites, including galactitol , which are toxic to various tissues.
  • • In classical galactosemia, the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase is deficient. This enzyme normally converts galactose-1-phosphate (derived from lactose in milk) into glucose-1-phosphate. The deficiency leads to accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate and its metabolites, including galactitol , which are toxic to various tissues.
  • • galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase
  • • This enzyme normally converts galactose-1-phosphate (derived from lactose in milk) into glucose-1-phosphate. The deficiency leads to accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate and its metabolites, including galactitol , which are toxic to various tissues.
  • • This enzyme normally converts galactose-1-phosphate (derived from lactose in milk) into glucose-1-phosphate.
  • • galactose-1-phosphate
  • • The deficiency leads to accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate and its metabolites, including galactitol , which are toxic to various tissues.
  • • galactose-1-phosphate
  • • galactitol
  • • Key Clinical Features :
  • • Key Clinical Features
  • • Jaundice : Due to liver damage caused by the toxic metabolites. Poor Feeding and Weight Loss : Inability to metabolize galactose disrupts energy production. Urine Positive for Reducing Substances but Negative for Glucose : The reducing substance here is galactose , not glucose. This can be detected using Benedict’s test. Oil Drop Cataract : Accumulation of galactitol in the lens of the eye causes osmotic swelling and cataract formation. Mental Retardation : If untreated, chronic toxicity leads to neurodevelopmental delay.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male of presents with recurrent kidney stones since adolescence. Stone analysis reveals calcium oxalate. Blood and urine oxalate levels are raised. Given the early-onset and stone composition, which inherited metabolic disorder is most likely?
questions.explanation:

  • • Primary Hyperoxaluria : Caused by a defect in glyoxylate metabolism leading to overproduction of oxalate , which combines with calcium to form calcium oxalate stones . It is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by deficiencies of specific enzymes, most commonly: Type I : Deficiency of alanine-glyoxylate aminotransferase (AGT) . Type II : Deficiency of glyoxylate reductase/hydroxypyruvate reductase (GRHPR) . The excess oxalate is excreted in the urine, leading to stone formation and potential kidney damage. Key Features : Early-Onset : Symptoms typically start in childhood or adolescence with recurrent kidney stones. Elevated Blood and Urine Oxalate : The hallmark finding. Calcium Oxalate Stones : Frequent and recurrent stone formation, often resistant to dietary interventions. Progression : If untreated, oxalate crystals can deposit in tissues (systemic oxalosis), leading to renal failure.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic with recurrent episodes of a photosensitive rash, intermittent diarrhea, and mood swings. His teacher has also reported difficulties in concentration at school. On examination, the child appears to have some cerebellar signs including coordination problems. Urinalysis shows an elevated excretion of neutral amino acids. Based on the findings, which amino acid deficiency is most characteristic of the child's likely inherited metabolic disorder?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Tryptophan

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The clinical presentation— photosensitive rash , diarrhea , CNS symptoms (mood swings, coordination problems) , and elevated excretion of neutral amino acids —is characteristic of Hartnup disease , an autosomal recessive disorder affecting the transport of neutral amino acids, particularly tryptophan , in the kidneys and intestines.
  • • photosensitive rash
  • • diarrhea
  • • CNS symptoms (mood swings, coordination problems)
  • • excretion of neutral amino acids
  • • Hartnup disease
  • • tryptophan
  • • Hartnup Disease : Caused by a defect in the SLC6A19 transporter , which impairs the reabsorption of neutral amino acids (like tryptophan) in the renal tubules and intestines. This leads to tryptophan deficiency and its decreased conversion to niacin (Vitamin B3) . Symptoms Resembling Pellagra : Tryptophan is a precursor for niacin synthesis. Deficiency of niacin causes symptoms known as pellagra , summarized as the "4 Ds" : Dermatitis : Photosensitive rash on sun-exposed areas (face, neck, hands). Diarrhea : Gastrointestinal disturbances. Dementia : Cognitive issues, mood swings, and difficulties in concentration. Death : If untreated. Neurological symptoms such as cerebellar ataxia (coordination problems) and mood swings are also common. Biochemical Findings : Elevated Excretion of Neutral Amino Acids : In Hartnup disease, neutral amino acids like tryptophan spill into the urine due to defective reabsorption in the renal tubules. Tryptophan-Niacin Conversion : Approximately 60 mg of tryptophan is required to produce 1 mg of niacin . Therefore, tryptophan deficiency leads to a niacin deficiency , causing pellagra-like symptoms.

questions.text: Following a specific point mutation, a lysine residue gets replaced by an aspartic acid residue in a protein. This alteration affects the protein's overall charge. What will happen to the mobility towards anode, of this mutated protein compared to the normal protein on gel electrophoresis?

options.label: A
options.text: Faster due to decreased overall positive charge.

options.label: B
options.text: Slower due to increased overall negative charge.

options.label: C
options.text: Dependent on the pH of the gel

questions.correct_answer: A. Faster due to decreased overall positive charge.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Faster due to decreased overall positive charge.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Lysine is a positively charged amino acid, while aspartic acid carries a negative charge at physiological pH. When lysine is replaced by aspartic acid, the protein's overall charge becomes more negative due to the loss of a positive charge and the addition of a negative charge.
  • • In gel electrophoresis, proteins move towards the anode (positive electrode) because they are negatively charged under standard electrophoresis conditions. The increased overall negative charge caused by the mutation enhances the protein’s movement towards the anode, resulting in faster mobility compared to the normal protein.
  • • anode
  • • faster mobility
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Slower due to increased overall negative charge: This is incorrect because increased negative charge would accelerate the protein's movement towards the positively charged anode, not slow it down.
  • • Option B. Slower due to increased overall negative charge:
  • • accelerate
  • • Option C. Dependent on the pH of the gel: While pH can affect protein charge, the question describes a very specific mutation leading to a clear charge shift. Given this specificity, the answer does not depend on the pH but rather on the increase in negative charge.
  • • Option C. Dependent on the pH of the gel:
  • • Option D. Unchanged: This is incorrect because replacing a positively charged lysine with a negatively charged aspartic acid clearly alters the overall charge, changing the protein’s mobility in gel electrophoresis.
  • • Option D. Unchanged:
  • • clearly alters

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The replacement of lysine (positive charge) with aspartic acid (negative charge) increases the overall negative charge of the protein, resulting in faster movement towards the anode in gel electrophoresis.
  • ➤ faster movement towards the anode

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with symptoms of peripheral neuropathy and mild hepatosplenomegaly. On examination, the tonsils appear notably enlarged and have an orange-yellow hue. Laboratory investigations reveal a remarkably low level of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol. Which inherited metabolic disorder is most likely responsible for this clinical presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tangier disease

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Tangier disease, also known as familial alpha-lipoprotein deficiency , is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ABCA1 gene . This gene encodes a transmembrane protein responsible for transferring cellular cholesterol to apolipoprotein A1, which is necessary for the formation of HDL (high-density lipoprotein).
  • • familial alpha-lipoprotein deficiency
  • • ABCA1 gene
  • • HDL
  • • Key Clinical Features:
  • • Key Clinical Features:
  • • Extremely low HDL cholesterol levels – This is a hallmark of Tangier disease. Orange-yellow tonsils – Caused by cholesterol accumulation in macrophages of the tonsils, giving them a characteristic appearance. Peripheral neuropathy – Due to cholesterol buildup in peripheral nerves. Hepatosplenomegaly – Cholesterol accumulation occurs in the liver and spleen. Cholesterol deposits in other tissues, including lymph nodes and the cornea.
  • • Extremely low HDL cholesterol levels – This is a hallmark of Tangier disease.
  • • Extremely low HDL cholesterol levels
  • • Orange-yellow tonsils – Caused by cholesterol accumulation in macrophages of the tonsils, giving them a characteristic appearance.
  • • Orange-yellow tonsils
  • • Peripheral neuropathy – Due to cholesterol buildup in peripheral nerves.
  • • Peripheral neuropathy
  • • Hepatosplenomegaly – Cholesterol accumulation occurs in the liver and spleen.
  • • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • • Cholesterol deposits in other tissues, including lymph nodes and the cornea.
  • • Cholesterol deposits
  • • The unique clinical finding of orange-yellow tonsils combined with peripheral neuropathy and low HDL levels makes Tangier disease the most likely diagnosis.
  • • orange-yellow tonsils
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Niemann-Pick disease: Niemann-Pick disease involves a deficiency of sphingomyelinase leading to accumulation of sphingomyelin. While it can present with hepatosplenomegaly and neurological symptoms, it does not cause low HDL or orange-yellow tonsils .
  • • Option A. Niemann-Pick disease:
  • • sphingomyelinase
  • • not cause low HDL or orange-yellow tonsils
  • • Option C. Fabry disease: Fabry disease is caused by a deficiency of α-galactosidase A , leading to accumulation of globotriaosylceramide. It presents with angiokeratomas, neuropathic pain, and renal failure, but does not cause low HDL or enlarged tonsils .
  • • Option C. Fabry disease:
  • • α-galactosidase A
  • • does not cause low HDL or enlarged tonsils
  • • Option D. Familial hypercholesterolemia: Familial hypercholesterolemia is characterized by elevated LDL cholesterol due to defects in the LDL receptor or its ligand (ApoB-100). It causes xanthomas and atherosclerosis but does not cause low HDL levels or orange-yellow tonsils .
  • • Option D. Familial hypercholesterolemia:
  • • LDL receptor
  • • not cause low HDL levels or orange-yellow tonsils

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tangier disease is caused by mutations in the ABCA1 gene , leading to extremely low HDL levels , cholesterol accumulation, orange-yellow tonsils , peripheral neuropathy, and hepatosplenomegaly.
  • ➤ ABCA1 gene
  • ➤ low HDL levels
  • ➤ orange-yellow tonsils

questions.text: The image depicts a nucleotide. If this nucleotide is added to a developing DNA sequence during a PCR process, what is the expected outcome?

options.label: C
options.text: The rate of DNA synthesis decreases

options.label: D
options.text: A glowing or fluorescent reaction is produced.

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Synthesis of DNA stops.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The structure depicted in the image is a dideoxynucleotide (ddNTP) .
  • • dideoxynucleotide (ddNTP)
  • • Key feature of ddNTPs : Unlike regular deoxynucleotides (dNTPs), ddNTPs lack both the 2’-hydroxyl group (2’-OH) and the 3’-hydroxyl group (3’-OH) on the sugar component. Role of the 3’-OH group in DNA synthesis : During DNA synthesis, the 3’-OH group of the growing DNA strand forms a phosphodiester bond with the incoming nucleotide’s phosphate group. Since ddNTPs lack the 3’-OH group , no further nucleotides can be added after a ddNTP is incorporated, leading to termination of DNA synthesis . Application in PCR : ddNTPs are commonly used in Sanger sequencing to terminate DNA synthesis at specific points. By adding fluorescently abelled ddNTPs, researchers can determine the sequence of the DNA strand.
  • • Key feature of ddNTPs : Unlike regular deoxynucleotides (dNTPs), ddNTPs lack both the 2’-hydroxyl group (2’-OH) and the 3’-hydroxyl group (3’-OH) on the sugar component.
  • • Key feature of ddNTPs
  • • ddNTPs lack both the 2’-hydroxyl group (2’-OH)
  • • 3’-hydroxyl group (3’-OH)
  • • Role of the 3’-OH group in DNA synthesis : During DNA synthesis, the 3’-OH group of the growing DNA strand forms a phosphodiester bond with the incoming nucleotide’s phosphate group. Since ddNTPs lack the 3’-OH group , no further nucleotides can be added after a ddNTP is incorporated, leading to termination of DNA synthesis .
  • • Role of the 3’-OH group in DNA synthesis

questions.text: A postgraduate student aims to establish a genomic library of a human cell line in Escherichia coli cells. To do so, she must slice both the E. coli plasmid DNA and human cell DNA with a restriction enzyme known to always target palindromic DNA sequences. Which among the following DNA sequences is palindromic and could potentially be recognized by this enzyme?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) GTGCAC

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • A palindromic DNA sequence is one in which the sequence of bases on the 5’ to 3’ strand is identical to the sequence on the complementary strand (3’ to 5’) when read in the opposite direction .
  • • palindromic DNA sequence
  • • 5’ to 3’ strand
  • • complementary strand (3’ to 5’)
  • • opposite direction
  • • Original strand (5’ → 3’): GTGCAC Complementary strand (3’ → 5’): CACGTG When you read the complementary strand in the 5’ → 3’ direction, it is: GTGCAC . This matches the original sequence, so it is palindromic .
  • • Original strand (5’ → 3’): GTGCAC
  • • GTGCAC
  • • Complementary strand (3’ → 5’): CACGTG When you read the complementary strand in the 5’ → 3’ direction, it is: GTGCAC . This matches the original sequence, so it is palindromic .
  • • CACGTG
  • • 5’ → 3’
  • • GTGCAC
  • • palindromic
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. AAGAAG: Complementary strand: TTCTTC → This does not match the original sequence when read in reverse. Not palindromic.
  • • Option A. AAGAAG:
  • • TTCTTC
  • • Not palindromic.
  • • Option B. CATCTA: Complementary strand: GTAGAT → This does not match the original sequence in reverse. Not palindromic.
  • • Option B. CATCTA:
  • • GTAGAT
  • • Not palindromic.
  • • Option C. TAGGAT: Complementary strand: ATCCTA → This does not match the original sequence when reversed. Not palindromic.
  • • Option C. TAGGAT:
  • • ATCCTA
  • • Not palindromic.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A palindromic DNA sequence reads the same in the 5’ → 3’ direction on one strand and the 5’ → 3’ direction on its complementary strand. The correct sequence here is GTGCAC .
  • ➤ palindromic DNA sequence
  • ➤ GTGCAC

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a history of heightened sensitivity to sunlight, resulting in severe skin lesions after minimal sun exposure. She also has a family history of early-onset cancers, especially skin malignancies. AP endonuclease cleaves the DNA backbone at the AP site. DNA polymerase fills the gap, and DNA ligase seals the strand.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents to the clinic with a triad of symptoms: confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia. On further questioning, he reports a history of chronic alcohol abuse. Physical examination reveals bilateral nystagmus and a broad-based gait. Given these clinical findings, which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vitamin B1 (thiamine)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The triad of confusion , ophthalmoplegia , and ataxia in a patient with a history of chronic alcohol abuse is highly characteristic of Wernicke's encephalopathy . This condition results from a deficiency of Vitamin B1 (thiamine) .

  • • Thiamine (Vitamin B1) is an essential cofactor for enzymes involved in carbohydrate metabolism, particularly: Pyruvate dehydrogenase (converts pyruvate to acetyl-CoA) α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase (TCA cycle) Transketolase (pentose phosphate pathway) Chronic alcohol use impairs thiamine absorption, storage, and utilization, leading to thiamine deficiency .
  • • Thiamine (Vitamin B1) is an essential cofactor for enzymes involved in carbohydrate metabolism, particularly: Pyruvate dehydrogenase (converts pyruvate to acetyl-CoA) α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase (TCA cycle) Transketolase (pentose phosphate pathway)
  • • Pyruvate dehydrogenase (converts pyruvate to acetyl-CoA) α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase (TCA cycle) Transketolase (pentose phosphate pathway)
  • • Pyruvate dehydrogenase (converts pyruvate to acetyl-CoA)
  • • Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  • • α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase (TCA cycle)
  • • α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
  • • Transketolase (pentose phosphate pathway)
  • • Transketolase
  • • Chronic alcohol use impairs thiamine absorption, storage, and utilization, leading to thiamine deficiency .
  • • thiamine deficiency
  • • Clinical Features of Wernicke's Encephalopathy:
  • • Clinical Features of Wernicke's Encephalopathy:
  • • Confusion – Global confusion and disorientation. Ophthalmoplegia – Paralysis or weakness of eye muscles, often leading to nystagmus . Ataxia – Unsteady, broad-based gait due to cerebellar involvement.
  • • Confusion – Global confusion and disorientation.
  • • Confusion
  • • Ophthalmoplegia – Paralysis or weakness of eye muscles, often leading to nystagmus .
  • • Ophthalmoplegia
  • • nystagmus
  • • Ataxia – Unsteady, broad-based gait due to cerebellar involvement.
  • • Ataxia
  • • If untreated, Wernicke's encephalopathy can progress to Korsakoff syndrome , which includes irreversible memory loss , confabulation , and psychosis .
  • • Korsakoff syndrome
  • • irreversible memory loss
  • • confabulation
  • • psychosis
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Vitamin B12: Vitamin B12 deficiency causes subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, leading to peripheral neuropathy, paresthesia, and ataxia but not ophthalmoplegia or confusion.
  • • Option A. Vitamin B12:
  • • subacute combined degeneration
  • • Option B. Vitamin C: Vitamin C deficiency leads to scurvy , which is characterized by bleeding gums, petechiae, and poor wound healing, not neurological symptoms.
  • • Option B. Vitamin C:
  • • scurvy
  • • Option C. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency causes osteomalacia (in adults) or rickets (in children), leading to bone pain and weakness but not neurological symptoms.
  • • Option C. Vitamin D:
  • • osteomalacia
  • • rickets

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wernicke's encephalopathy is caused by Vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency , commonly seen in chronic alcoholics. The classic triad includes:
  • ➤ Wernicke's encephalopathy
  • ➤ Vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency

  • ➤ Confusion
  • ➤ Confusion

  • ➤ Ophthalmoplegia
  • ➤ Ataxia
  • ➤ Ataxia

questions.text: A 6-month-old male infant is brought to the clinic with hypotonia, seizures, and sparse light colored hair. Upon further investigation, laboratory results show abnormal serum levels of a specific mineral, and a copper-transport protein. What is your diagnosis:

  • • 1. Clinical Presentation
  • • Hypotonia (poor muscle tone) Seizures Sparse, light-colored, and brittle ("kinky") hair – Due to a lack of tyrosinase , which is copper-dependent for melanin production. Developmental delay and growth retardation Failure to thrive
  • • Hypotonia (poor muscle tone)
  • • Hypotonia
  • • Seizures
  • • Seizures
  • • Sparse, light-colored, and brittle ("kinky") hair – Due to a lack of tyrosinase , which is copper-dependent for melanin production.
  • • Sparse, light-colored, and brittle ("kinky") hair

  • • Developmental delay and growth retardation
  • • Developmental delay and growth retardation
  • • Failure to thrive
  • • Failure to thrive

  • • tyrosinase

  • • "kinky"

Presents later (childhood/adolescence) with Kayser-Fleischer rings , liver disease, and neurological symptoms. Serum copper and ceruloplasmin are low, but tissue copper (liver/brain) is high.

questions.text: A teenager suffering from the deficiency of muscle phosphorylase is getting examined by a rubber ball squeezing test while exercising her forearm. Which of following statements will be true for this patient compared to a normal person?

options.label: B
options.text: ↑ blood glucose in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein.

options.label: C
options.text: ↑ blood lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein.

options.label: D
options.text: Relatively ↓ blood lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein.

questions.correct_answer: D. Relatively ↓ blood lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Relatively ↓ blood lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In a patient with muscle phosphorylase deficiency, also known as McArdle's disease , the breakdown of glycogen in muscles is impaired. Muscle phosphorylase is required to convert glycogen into glucose-1-phosphate, which is then converted into glucose-6-phosphate to enter glycolysis. Under normal conditions, during exercise (anaerobic conditions), glycolysis produces pyruvate, which is converted into lactate and enters the blood. This leads to an increase in blood lactate levels in a normal person.
  • • McArdle's disease
  • • lactate
  • • However, in McArdle's disease:
  • • Glycogen cannot be broken down due to the lack of muscle phosphorylase. This means glucose-6-phosphate is not formed, and glycolysis cannot proceed efficiently. As a result, there is no significant lactate production during exercise. Blood lactate levels, therefore, remain relatively low compared to normal individuals.
  • • Glycogen cannot be broken down due to the lack of muscle phosphorylase.
  • • This means glucose-6-phosphate is not formed, and glycolysis cannot proceed efficiently.
  • • As a result, there is no significant lactate production during exercise.
  • • no significant lactate production
  • • Blood lactate levels, therefore, remain relatively low compared to normal individuals.
  • • Thus, the characteristic feature of McArdle's disease is the absence of a rise in blood lactate during exercise.
  • • characteristic feature of McArdle's disease
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Exercise endurance: Patients with McArdle's disease have poor exercise endurance because they cannot mobilize glycogen for energy production in muscles. This option does not directly describe the blood lactate changes.
  • • Option A. Exercise endurance:
  • • Option B. ↑ blood glucose in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein: Blood glucose is primarily regulated by liver glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis, not muscle glycogen breakdown. McArdle's disease affects muscle phosphorylase, not liver phosphorylase, so this statement is incorrect.
  • • Option B. ↑ blood glucose in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein:
  • • Option C. ↑ blood lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein: In normal individuals, blood lactate increases during exercise due to glycolysis in muscles. In McArdle's disease, muscle phosphorylase deficiency prevents glycogenolysis and lactate production, so blood lactate does not increase. This option is incorrect.
  • • Option C. ↑ blood lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein:
  • • not

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The characteristic feature of McArdle's disease (muscle phosphorylase deficiency) is the absence of a rise in blood lactate during exercise due to impaired glycogen breakdown in muscles.
  • ➤ characteristic feature
  • ➤ the absence of a rise in blood lactate

questions.text: A young boy comes to the clinic with coarse facial features, an enlarged abdomen, a prominent forehead, heart valve thickening, enlarged liver and spleen, and hearing difficulties. Notably, there is no haziness in his corneas. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:

It leads to the accumulation of glycosaminoglycans (GAGs), including dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate. Characteristic features include: Coarse facial features Hepatosplenomegaly (enlarged liver and spleen) Heart valve thickening Hearing difficulties No corneal clouding (key differentiating feature from Hurler’s syndrome) Death typically occurs in the second decade of life.
  • • Hunter’s syndrome is an X-linked recessive lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme iduronate-2-sulfatase . It leads to the accumulation of glycosaminoglycans (GAGs), including dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate. Characteristic features include: Coarse facial features Hepatosplenomegaly (enlarged liver and spleen) Heart valve thickening Hearing difficulties No corneal clouding (key differentiating feature from Hurler’s syndrome) Death typically occurs in the second decade of life.
  • • X-linked recessive
  • • iduronate-2-sulfatase
  • • It leads to the accumulation of glycosaminoglycans (GAGs), including dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate. Characteristic features include: Coarse facial features Hepatosplenomegaly (enlarged liver and spleen) Heart valve thickening Hearing difficulties No corneal clouding (key differentiating feature from Hurler’s syndrome) Death typically occurs in the second decade of life.
  • • It leads to the accumulation of glycosaminoglycans (GAGs), including dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate.
  • • Characteristic features include: Coarse facial features Hepatosplenomegaly (enlarged liver and spleen) Heart valve thickening Hearing difficulties No corneal clouding (key differentiating feature from Hurler’s syndrome)
  • • Coarse facial features Hepatosplenomegaly (enlarged liver and spleen) Heart valve thickening Hearing difficulties No corneal clouding (key differentiating feature from Hurler’s syndrome)
  • • Coarse facial features
  • • Hepatosplenomegaly (enlarged liver and spleen)
  • • Heart valve thickening
  • • Hearing difficulties
  • • Hearing difficulties
  • • No corneal clouding (key differentiating feature from Hurler’s syndrome)
  • • No corneal clouding

  • • Option A. Gaucher's disease: Caused by a deficiency of beta-glucocerebrosidase , leading to glucocerebroside accumulation. It primarily causes hepatosplenomegaly, bone pain, and neurological symptoms but does not cause coarse facial features or heart valve thickening .
  • • Option A. Gaucher's disease:
  • • beta-glucocerebrosidase
  • • not cause coarse facial features or heart valve thickening
  • • Option C. Hurler’s disease: Hurler’s syndrome shares similar features but is caused by a deficiency of alpha-L-iduronidase . Unlike Hunter’s syndrome, Hurler’s presents with corneal clouding , which is absent in this case.

  • • Note:

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 50-year-old man who drank too much alcohol fell in the street. He was quickly taken to the hospital. What is the first line treatment to be given to this patient in ER?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vitamin B1

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In patients with alcohol intoxication , there is a high risk of thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency , which can cause or worsen a condition known as Wernicke's encephalopathy . Wernicke’s encephalopathy is an acute neurological emergency characterized by:
  • • alcohol intoxication
  • • thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency
  • • Wernicke's encephalopathy
  • • Confusion Ataxia (loss of coordination) Ophthalmoplegia (eye muscle paralysis)
  • • Confusion
  • • Confusion
  • • Ataxia (loss of coordination)
  • • Ataxia
  • • Ophthalmoplegia (eye muscle paralysis)
  • • Ophthalmoplegia
  • • Role of Thiamine (Vitamin B1):
  • • Role of Thiamine (Vitamin B1):
  • • Thiamine is a cofactor for several important enzymes, including pyruvate dehydrogenase , which is required for the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA in the link reaction of glucose metabolism. In thiamine deficiency, if glucose is administered before thiamine , pyruvate accumulates and is converted to lactate , leading to lactic acidosis and worsening the patient's condition.
  • • Thiamine is a cofactor for several important enzymes, including pyruvate dehydrogenase , which is required for the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA in the link reaction of glucose metabolism.
  • • pyruvate dehydrogenase
  • • conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA
  • • In thiamine deficiency, if glucose is administered before thiamine , pyruvate accumulates and is converted to lactate , leading to lactic acidosis and worsening the patient's condition.
  • • before thiamine
  • • lactate
  • • lactic acidosis
  • • Treatment Protocol:
  • • Treatment Protocol:
  • • Administer Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) first to prevent Wernicke’s encephalopathy and lactic acidosis. After thiamine, glucose can be administered slowly and gradually to restore energy balance without causing pyruvate accumulation.
  • • Administer Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) first to prevent Wernicke’s encephalopathy and lactic acidosis.
  • • Administer Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) first
  • • After thiamine, glucose can be administered slowly and gradually to restore energy balance without causing pyruvate accumulation.
  • • glucose
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Glucose: Administering glucose before thiamine in a patient with thiamine deficiency can worsen lactic acidosis. Therefore, glucose is given only after thiamine .
  • • Option B. Glucose:
  • • before thiamine
  • • after thiamine
  • • Option C. Fructose: Fructose is not used as a first-line treatment for alcohol intoxication and does not address thiamine deficiency or energy metabolism.
  • • Option C. Fructose:
  • • Option D. Vitamin B6: Vitamin B6 is involved in amino acid metabolism but does not address the acute issue of thiamine deficiency and Wernicke's encephalopathy.
  • • Option D. Vitamin B6:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of alcohol intoxication , the first-line treatment is Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) to prevent Wernicke's encephalopathy and lactic acidosis. Glucose administration should always follow thiamine supplementation.
  • ➤ alcohol intoxication
  • ➤ Vitamin B1 (Thiamine)

questions.text: ChIP is used for:

options.label: A
options.text: Protein DNA interactions and histone modifications

questions.correct_answer: A. Protein DNA interactions and histone modifications
questions.explanation:

In the process: Enzymes cleave the DNA at specific points to break it into smaller fragments. An antigen-antibody reaction occurs where antibodies bind to proteins attached to DNA. This protein-DNA complex is then precipitated, allowing researchers to analyze the specific DNA regions associated with proteins. It is particularly useful for identifying histone modifications or transcription factors bound to specific regions of the genome.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents to the outpatient clinic with a swollen abdomen and failure to thrive. On examination, his liver is palpable 4 cm below the right costal margin, and he has a doll-like face with chubby cheeks. Laboratory investigations reveal fasting hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, and hyperuricemia. A liver biopsy demonstrates increased glycogen storage with normal structure. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for this patient's clinical presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Glucose-6-phosphatase

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The clinical presentation of this patient is characteristic of Von Gierke Disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type I) , caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase .
  • • Von Gierke Disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type I)
  • • glucose-6-phosphatase
  • • Key Features of Von Gierke Disease : Fasting hypoglycemia : Glucose-6-phosphatase catalyzes the final step in gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis (conversion of glucose-6-phosphate to glucose). Without this enzyme, the liver cannot release glucose into the bloodstream during fasting, leading to severe hypoglycemia. Lactic acidosis : Accumulation of glucose-6-phosphate diverts metabolism toward glycolysis, producing pyruvate and subsequently lactic acid. Hyperuricemia : Excess glucose-6-phosphate increases purine metabolism, leading to uric acid buildup. Hepatomegaly : Glycogen accumulates in the liver because it cannot be broken down and released as free glucose. The structure of glycogen remains normal. Doll-like face with chubby cheeks : Due to increased fat synthesis and deposition from the excess glucose-6-phosphate. Biochemical Mechanism : Enzyme Deficiency : Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency prevents the conversion of glucose-6-phosphate to glucose. Pathway Blockage : Gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis both fail to release glucose into the blood.
  • • Key Features of Von Gierke Disease : Fasting hypoglycemia : Glucose-6-phosphatase catalyzes the final step in gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis (conversion of glucose-6-phosphate to glucose). Without this enzyme, the liver cannot release glucose into the bloodstream during fasting, leading to severe hypoglycemia. Lactic acidosis : Accumulation of glucose-6-phosphate diverts metabolism toward glycolysis, producing pyruvate and subsequently lactic acid. Hyperuricemia : Excess glucose-6-phosphate increases purine metabolism, leading to uric acid buildup. Hepatomegaly : Glycogen accumulates in the liver because it cannot be broken down and released as free glucose. The structure of glycogen remains normal. Doll-like face with chubby cheeks : Due to increased fat synthesis and deposition from the excess glucose-6-phosphate.

  • • Option B. Muscle glycogen phosphorylase: Deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase causes McArdle Disease (GSD Type V) , characterized by muscle weakness, cramps, and myoglobinuria during exercise. It does not affect the liver or cause fasting hypoglycemia.

  • • McArdle Disease (GSD Type V)

  • • Tarui Disease (GSD Type VII)

questions.text: Two children with genetic issues related to fructose processing saw the same doctor. One child’s parents were told to limit fructose in the diet due to health concerns. However, the second child's parents were told their kid wouldn't likely have any problems, even though both kids had fructose in their blood and urine. Based on this, what enzyme conversion is deficient in the second child?
questions.correct_answer: A. Conversion of fructose into fructose-1-phosphate
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Conversion of fructose into fructose-1-phosphate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The second child’s condition, where fructose appears in blood and urine but does not cause any health issues, is consistent with Essential Fructosuria . This condition is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme fructokinase .
  • • Essential Fructosuria
  • • fructokinase
  • • Fructokinase Role in Metabolism :
  • • Fructokinase Role in Metabolism
  • • Fructokinase catalyzes the conversion of fructose into fructose-1-phosphate . In its absence, fructose cannot be phosphorylated and remains in the bloodstream, where it is filtered by the kidneys and excreted in the urine.
  • • Fructokinase catalyzes the conversion of fructose into fructose-1-phosphate .
  • • fructose into fructose-1-phosphate
  • • In its absence, fructose cannot be phosphorylated and remains in the bloodstream, where it is filtered by the kidneys and excreted in the urine.
  • • Key Features of Essential Fructosuria :
  • • Key Features of Essential Fructosuria
  • • Benign Condition : It is an asymptomatic condition because fructose does not accumulate in toxic forms in the body. Fructose in Blood and Urine : Fructose appears in the blood (fructosemia) and urine (fructosuria) but causes no clinical symptoms. No Dietary Restrictions Needed : Unlike hereditary fructose intolerance (HFI), patients with essential fructosuria do not require dietary modifications.
  • • Benign Condition : It is an asymptomatic condition because fructose does not accumulate in toxic forms in the body.
  • • Benign Condition
  • • Fructose in Blood and Urine : Fructose appears in the blood (fructosemia) and urine (fructosuria) but causes no clinical symptoms.
  • • Fructose in Blood and Urine
  • • No Dietary Restrictions Needed : Unlike hereditary fructose intolerance (HFI), patients with essential fructosuria do not require dietary modifications.
  • • No Dietary Restrictions Needed
  • • Comparison with Hereditary Fructose Intolerance (HFI) :
  • • Comparison with Hereditary Fructose Intolerance (HFI)
  • • HFI is caused by a deficiency of aldolase B , which breaks down fructose-1-phosphate into glyceraldehyde and dihydroxyacetone-phosphate (DHAP). HFI leads to the accumulation of fructose-1-phosphate , which is toxic and causes symptoms such as jaundice, hepatomegaly, vomiting, and hypoglycemia when fructose is ingested. The first child likely has HFI (aldolase B deficiency) and requires dietary restrictions. The second child has Essential Fructosuria (fructokinase deficiency), which is benign and does not require treatment.
  • • HFI is caused by a deficiency of aldolase B , which breaks down fructose-1-phosphate into glyceraldehyde and dihydroxyacetone-phosphate (DHAP).

The first child likely has HFI (aldolase B deficiency) and requires dietary restrictions. The second child has Essential Fructosuria (fructokinase deficiency), which is benign and does not require treatment.

  • • The first child likely has HFI (aldolase B deficiency) and requires dietary restrictions.
  • • first child
  • • HFI
  • • The second child has Essential Fructosuria (fructokinase deficiency), which is benign and does not require treatment.
  • • second child
  • • Essential Fructosuria
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Changing of fructose-1-phosphate into glyceraldehyde: This step is catalyzed by aldolase B and is defective in hereditary fructose intolerance , not in essential fructosuria.
  • • Option B. Changing of fructose-1-phosphate into glyceraldehyde:
  • • aldolase B
  • • hereditary fructose intolerance
  • • Option C. Changing of fructose-1-phosphate into dihydroxyacetone-phosphate: Also part of aldolase B function, affected in HFI.
  • • Option C. Changing of fructose-1-phosphate into dihydroxyacetone-phosphate:
  • • Option D. Conversion of glyceraldehyde into glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate: This step involves triose kinase and is not related to fructokinase deficiency or benign fructosuria.
  • • Option D. Conversion of glyceraldehyde into glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate:
  • • triose kinase

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Essential Fructosuria is caused by a deficiency of fructokinase , leading to the inability to convert fructose into fructose-1-phosphate. It is a benign condition with no symptoms other than fructose excretion in urine.
  • ➤ Essential Fructosuria
  • ➤ fructokinase
  • ➤ benign condition

questions.text: A 5-day-old neonate is brought to the pediatric outpatient department with poor feeding, irritability, and lethargy. The parents mention a distinctive sweet odor emanating from the baby's urine. A metabolic disorder is suspected. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is most consistent with this neonate's presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase complex.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The clinical presentation described here is characteristic of Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) , a rare inherited metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase complex (BCKDC) .
  • • Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD)
  • • branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase complex (BCKDC)
  • • Key Clinical Features of MSUD : Distinctive Sweet Odor : The urine smells like maple syrup or burnt sugar, due to the accumulation of branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) and their keto acids. Poor Feeding, Irritability, and Lethargy : Symptoms result from the accumulation of neurotoxic metabolites. Age of Onset : Symptoms typically appear within the first few days of life . Metabolic Crisis : If untreated, it can lead to seizures, developmental delay, and even death. Biochemical Basis of MSUD : The branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase complex (BCKDC) is required for the oxidative decarboxylation of the keto acids derived from the catabolism of branched-chain amino acids: Leucine Isoleucine Valine Deficiency of this enzyme leads to the accumulation of these amino acids and their keto acids in the blood, urine, and tissues, causing toxicity. Vitamin B1 Requirement : The BCKDC requires Thiamine (Vitamin B1) as a cofactor for its activity. In some milder cases, thiamine supplementation can help improve enzyme function.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the orthopedic clinic with complaints of chronic joint pain, especially in his knees and hips. On examination, his ear cartilage displays a bluish-black discoloration. Additionally, the patient has a history of recurrent kidney stones and mentions a progressive stiffening of his spine. Based on these clinical findings, which symptom is most characteristic of the likely inherited metabolic disorder?
questions.correct_answer: B. Darkening of urine upon standing
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Darkening of urine upon standing

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The clinical findings described here— bluish-black discoloration of ear cartilage (ochronosis), chronic joint pain, progressive spinal stiffening, and recurrent kidney stones—are characteristic of Alkaptonuria , an inherited metabolic disorder.
  • • bluish-black discoloration of ear cartilage
  • • Alkaptonuria
  • • Biochemical Basis of Alkaptonuria :
  • • Biochemical Basis of Alkaptonuria
  • • Alkaptonuria is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme homogentisate dioxygenase . This enzyme is involved in the breakdown of tyrosine and phenylalanine . Deficiency leads to accumulation of homogentisic acid (HGA) , which is excreted in urine and deposited in tissues.
  • • Alkaptonuria is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme homogentisate dioxygenase . This enzyme is involved in the breakdown of tyrosine and phenylalanine . Deficiency leads to accumulation of homogentisic acid (HGA) , which is excreted in urine and deposited in tissues.
  • • homogentisate dioxygenase
  • • This enzyme is involved in the breakdown of tyrosine and phenylalanine . Deficiency leads to accumulation of homogentisic acid (HGA) , which is excreted in urine and deposited in tissues.
  • • This enzyme is involved in the breakdown of tyrosine and phenylalanine .
  • • tyrosine
  • • phenylalanine
  • • Deficiency leads to accumulation of homogentisic acid (HGA) , which is excreted in urine and deposited in tissues.
  • • homogentisic acid (HGA)
  • • Key Features of Alkaptonuria :
  • • Key Features of Alkaptonuria
  • • Darkening of Urine : Homogentisic acid is oxidized upon standing, causing the urine to turn black —a pathognomonic feature of alkaptonuria. Ochronosis : Deposition of homogentisic acid in connective tissues leads to bluish-black discoloration of cartilage, sclera, and skin. Chronic Joint Pain : Long-term deposition of homogentisic acid in joints causes degenerative arthritis , particularly in the spine , hips, and knees. Recurrent Kidney Stones : HGA can crystallize in the urine, contributing to kidney stone formation.

  • • Ochronosis

  • • Chronic Joint Pain : Long-term deposition of homogentisic acid in joints causes degenerative arthritis , particularly in the spine , hips, and knees.
  • • Chronic Joint Pain

  • • spine
  • • Recurrent Kidney Stones : HGA can crystallize in the urine, contributing to kidney stone formation.
  • • Recurrent Kidney Stones : HGA can crystallize in the urine, contributing to kidney stone formation.
  • • Recurrent Kidney Stones
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Hepatosplenomegaly: Hepatosplenomegaly is associated with lysosomal storage disorders such as Gaucher disease or Niemann-Pick disease , not alkaptonuria.
  • • Option A. Hepatosplenomegaly:
  • • Gaucher disease
  • • Niemann-Pick disease
  • • Option C. Lens Dislocation: Lens dislocation (ectopia lentis) is characteristic of homocystinuria , not alkaptonuria.
  • • Option C. Lens Dislocation:
  • • homocystinuria
  • • Option D. Hypoglycemic Episodes: Hypoglycemia is seen in disorders such as glycogen storage diseases or gluconeogenesis defects , not in alkaptonuria.
  • • Option D. Hypoglycemic Episodes:
  • • glycogen storage diseases
  • • gluconeogenesis defects

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with episodes of irritability, vomiting, and rapid breathing. The mother mentions that the symptoms seemed to worsen after high-protein meals. Laboratory findings indicate elevated ammonia levels in the blood. Citrulline cannot be found in plasma amino acid analysis, however his urinary orotic acid level is elevated. Given the clinical picture and the boy's age, an inherited metabolic disorder is suspected. Which enzyme reaction is most likely affected in this patient's condition? Conversion of ornithine to citrulline Conversion of citrulline to argininosuccinate Conversion of carbamoyl phosphate to citrulline Conversion of arginine to ornithine
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)  B and C both

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The urea cycle involves the stepwise conversion of nitrogenous waste (ammonia) into urea for excretion. The clinical presentation of this patient— hyperammonemia , absence of citrulline in plasma, and elevated orotic acid in urine —suggests a defect in Ornithine Transcarbamoylase (OTC) activity, the enzyme responsible for converting carbamoyl phosphate and ornithine into citrulline .
  • • urea

  • • citrulline
  • • elevated orotic acid in urine
  • • Ornithine Transcarbamoylase (OTC)
  • • carbamoyl phosphate
  • • ornithine
  • • citrulline
  • • Option B. Conversion of citrulline to argininosuccinate:
  • • Option B. Conversion of citrulline to argininosuccinate:
  • • The downstream step in the urea cycle involves converting citrulline to argininosuccinate using the enzyme argininosuccinate synthetase . While the direct defect here is in OTC , lack of citrulline availability due to upstream enzyme failure means this reaction is also indirectly affected. Without citrulline, argininosuccinate formation cannot occur .
  • • The downstream step in the urea cycle involves converting citrulline to argininosuccinate using the enzyme argininosuccinate synthetase . While the direct defect here is in OTC , lack of citrulline availability due to upstream enzyme failure means this reaction is also indirectly affected. Without citrulline, argininosuccinate formation cannot occur .

  • • OTC

Deficiency of OTC prevents this step, leading to absence of citrulline and accumulation of carbamoyl phosphate. Excess carbamoyl phosphate leaks into the cytoplasm and stimulates pyrimidine synthesis , causing elevated urinary orotic acid .

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with motor weakness, exaggerated startle response, and a cherry-red spot-on macular examination. Lab investigation reveal elevated levels of gangliosides in cells. Which inherited metabolic disorder is most likely responsible for this clinical presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tay-Sachs disease

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Tay-Sachs disease is an inherited metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase A . This leads to the accumulation of GM2 gangliosides in neurons, causing neurodegeneration.
  • • hexosaminidase A
  • • GM2 gangliosides
  • • Key clinical features of Tay-Sachs disease include:
  • • Tay-Sachs disease
  • • Motor weakness – Infants lose motor skills as the disease progresses. Exaggerated startle response – A hyperactive reaction to sound or touch. Cherry-red spot on the macula – This occurs because the surrounding retinal cells are swollen with ganglioside accumulation, making the normal macula stand out. Absence of hepatosplenomegaly – Unlike other lysosomal storage disorders, gangliosides do not accumulate in the liver.
  • • Motor weakness – Infants lose motor skills as the disease progresses.
  • • Motor weakness
  • • Exaggerated startle response – A hyperactive reaction to sound or touch.
  • • Exaggerated startle response
  • • Cherry-red spot on the macula – This occurs because the surrounding retinal cells are swollen with ganglioside accumulation, making the normal macula stand out.
  • • Cherry-red spot on the macula
  • • Absence of hepatosplenomegaly – Unlike other lysosomal storage disorders, gangliosides do not accumulate in the liver.
  • • Absence of hepatosplenomegaly
  • • The presence of elevated gangliosides in cells, combined with the characteristic cherry-red spot and absence of hepatosplenomegaly, confirms Tay-Sachs disease.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Niemann-Pick disease: Niemann-Pick disease can present with a cherry-red spot, but it is accompanied by hepatosplenomegaly , which is absent in Tay-Sachs disease.
  • • Option A. Niemann-Pick disease:
  • • hepatosplenomegaly
  • • Option C. Gaucher's disease: Gaucher's disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by glucocerebrosidase deficiency. It presents with hepatosplenomegaly, bone pain, and anemia but does not involve gangliosides or a cherry-red spot .
  • • Option C. Gaucher's disease:
  • • does not involve gangliosides or a cherry-red spot
  • • Option D. Fabry disease: Fabry disease involves a deficiency of α-galactosidase A leading to accumulation of globotriaosylceramide. It presents with neuropathic pain, angiokeratomas, and renal failure, not cherry-red spots or ganglioside accumulation.
  • • Option D. Fabry disease:
  • • α-galactosidase A

  • ➤ exaggerated startle response
  • ➤ GM2 gangliosides
  • ➤ hexosaminidase A deficiency
  • ➤ no hepatosplenomegaly

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with recurrent episodes of acute pancreatitis. On physical examination, multiple eruptive xanthomas are noticed on the patient’s back and buttocks. Laboratory findings demonstrate significantly elevated serum triglyceride levels. Which inherited metabolic disorder is consistent with this clinical picture?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Type I hyperlipoproteinemia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Type I hyperlipoproteinemia , also known as familial hyperchylomicronemia , is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by a deficiency of lipoprotein lipase (LPL) or its cofactor Apo C-II .

  • • lipoprotein lipase (LPL)
  • • Apo C-II
  • • Key findings in Type I hyperlipoproteinemia:
  • • Markedly elevated triglyceride levels – This occurs due to the accumulation of chylomicrons , which transport triglycerides. Recurrent acute pancreatitis – High triglyceride levels (>1000 mg/dL) predispose patients to pancreatitis. Eruptive xanthomas – Small, yellow-red papules that appear on the back, buttocks, and extremities due to chylomicron deposition in the skin. No significant increase in cholesterol – Unlike other hyperlipidemias, cholesterol levels remain relatively normal.
  • • Markedly elevated triglyceride levels – This occurs due to the accumulation of chylomicrons , which transport triglycerides.
  • • Markedly elevated triglyceride levels
  • • chylomicrons
  • • Recurrent acute pancreatitis – High triglyceride levels (>1000 mg/dL) predispose patients to pancreatitis.

  • • Eruptive xanthomas
  • • No significant increase in cholesterol – Unlike other hyperlipidemias, cholesterol levels remain relatively normal.
  • • No significant increase in cholesterol
  • • The combination of recurrent pancreatitis , eruptive xanthomas , and elevated triglycerides points specifically to Type I hyperlipoproteinemia.
  • • recurrent pancreatitis
  • • eruptive xanthomas
  • • elevated triglycerides
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Familial combined hyperlipidemia: This condition is characterized by elevated LDL and VLDL levels, leading to increased triglycerides and cholesterol. It does not present with isolated severe triglyceridemia or eruptive xanthomas.

  • • LDL and VLDL
  • • Option B. Familial hypercholesterolemia: This is a Type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia caused by LDL receptor defects . It leads to isolated elevated cholesterol levels and features such as tendon xanthomas and early atherosclerosis but does not cause recurrent pancreatitis or eruptive xanthomas.
  • • Option B. Familial hypercholesterolemia:
  • • Type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia
  • • LDL receptor defects
  • • cholesterol levels
  • • Option D. Type IIb hyperlipoproteinemia: This condition results in increased LDL and VLDL levels , causing elevated cholesterol and triglycerides (combined hyperlipidemia). It does not present with eruptive xanthomas or such high triglycerides seen in Type I.

  • • Note:
